@dublincycling @dublinmarathon Seeing as majority of Irish AQ emissions are from domestic burning and temps are down this weekend, I'm not so sure you will see reductions. Pity we have so few real time AQ data points. Cycling out to Bray this AM I smelled coal, wood, petrol and Diesel.

Spot on @Shane_O_D ; @Paschald missed an opportunity in #Budget2019 to penalise Euro 1-5 and I-V imports and save us from dirty emissions. Import EV and Euro 6/VI by all means but tax the hell out of inefficient cars and trucks that will cost Irish owners money at pump in L/100km

@Emma_K_journo The way to reduce your energy bills is to reduce use. Invest your time, money (& grants) to reduce heat and electric demand, you will be more comfortable and better off. Last paragraph on #energyefficiency is not good enough should be first.

Now we might get people to see the cost savings per kWh vs Diesel and Petrol. Bring on the long promised billing, Ireland has one of the only integrated EV networks, let's work it properly. ESB charge EV users for use of charging stations https://t.co/xXe2kULJjN via @RTENewsNow
@willgoodbody About bloody time! Only way to accelerate the whole EV transition. Regulators must move faster!
@jeppe_juul @FoundrySquared @UnileverEU @transenv @Transport_EU @EU_ENV @Unilever Yes. Many HDV operators do not qualify too small too risky. Those that do use leasing and buy new vehicles.

@FoundrySquared I don't think so, improved fuel performance in aircraft and EU de-regulation has democratised air travel: Helping those on lower incomes fly. SME operators buy second hand, so it will be a trickle down effect. AQ is a different issue. Truck makers need regs or they will delay. https://t.co/AjdzYbRLyS

@dynamonanalytic Agree tyre choice can save fuel, but can you explain the 20-40%? Typically we see claims of 5-10%% (https://t.co/fosiSOpkci) and 3-5% in reality. Also no point in changing tyres if you don't inflate them correctly i.e. management is needed.

@FoundrySquared @UnileverEU @transenv @Transport_EU @EU_ENV Surely trucks with 20% less fuel costs will benefit the 540,000 SME transport operators across the EU? Roughly speaking -20% on fuel = 6% net profit in an industry with net margins of 3%. Simplistic I know, but @Unilever can help drive demand for fuel efficient trucks.
